importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the announcement of Pakistan's first hyperspectral satellite launch, a significant event in Pakistan's space development history.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The launch of Pakistan’s H1 satellite in 2025 is part of a broader national effort to advance space capabilities and technological self-reliance in agriculture and disaster management.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, into orbit via a launch from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre.
The H1 satellite is a major milestone for Pakistan’s space programme, marking the country's entry into hyperspectral remote sensing technology.
Hyperspectral satellites can detect subtle chemical and material changes on Earth’s surface, enabling precise monitoring of crop health, water resources, and disaster impacts.
The satellite supports national priorities in precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster risk assessment.
The launch is seen as a key step in advancing Pakistan’s space capabilities and strengthening its strategic partnership with China.
Pakistan’s space agency, SUPARCO, successfully launched the H1 satellite on Sunday, October 19, 2025, as part of a year in which Pakistan has sent three satellites into orbit.
The two previously launched satellites, EO-1 and KS-1, are already fully operational in orbit.
It is estimated that it will take about two months to calibrate the H1 satellite before it becomes fully operational.
The launch aligns with development goals such as the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), where geohazard monitoring is critical for infrastructure safety.
SUPARCO chairman Muhammad Yousuf Khan stated that the satellite data will revolutionize agricultural productivity, climate resilience, and natural resource management.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country that launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, into orbit in 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pakistan is the primary actor in the article, launching the H1 satellite as a key national achievement in space technology.

namedEntities.name: SUPARCO
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pakistan’s national space agency responsible for the launch and management of the H1 satellite.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SUPARCO is the central organizing body behind the satellite launch and is directly involved in advancing Pakistan’s space programme.

namedEntities.name: H1 satellite
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pakistan’s first hyperspectral satellite, launched into orbit on October 19, 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite is the technological centerpiece of the article, offering capabilities for agriculture, disaster monitoring, and environmental management.

namedEntities.name: Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A space launch facility in northwestern China used to launch the H1 satellite.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The launch occurred at Jiuquan, indicating international cooperation with China in space technology and operations.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nation with which Pakistan has a strategic partnership, particularly in space technology and the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC).
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China provided the launch site and is a key partner in Pakistan’s space collaboration, reflecting broader geopolitical ties.

namedEntities.name: China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major infrastructure development initiative linking Xinjiang, China, with Pakistan’s Gwadar Port.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite’s ability to monitor geohazards supports infrastructure safety within the CPEC, enhancing project resilience.

namedEntities.name: Muhammad Yousuf Khan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chairman of SUPARCO, who commented on the satellite’s potential impact on agriculture and climate resilience.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is a key spokesperson for the mission’s scientific and national development significance.

namedEntities.name: EO-1 and KS-1
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Two other satellites launched by Pakistan in 2025, which are already operational in orbit.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They provide context for Pakistan’s broader space programme growth and indicate progress in national space capabilities.

summaryOfNewsArticle: On October 19, 2025, Pakistan successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre, marking a major milestone in its space programme. The satellite, developed by SUPARCO, is designed to detect subtle material changes on Earth’s surface, enabling advanced monitoring of agriculture, water resources, and disaster risks. This launch is part of a broader national strategy to strengthen technological self-reliance and support critical development initiatives such as the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), where geohazard monitoring is essential. The H1 satellite is expected to become fully operational within two months, with data expected to enhance agricultural productivity, climate resilience, and natural resource management. The mission underscores Pakistan’s growing partnership with China in peaceful space exploration and technological advancement.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
